metadata.case_name: M/s. Navinchandra Co. v. Respondent Mills

facts.text: Appellants are partners of M/s. Navinchandra Co.

Appellants placed order with respondent for 251 bales of printed chintz on or about July 4, 1942, accepted by respondent by letters dated July 11 and July 20, 1942. Delivery period: September and October 1942.
Another order placed by appellants for 31 bales of printed chintz on July 24, 1942, accepted by respondent on July 25, 1942. Delivery: October 1942.
Workers in respondent mills went on strike on August 9, 1942, in sympathy with Quit India movement.

Respondent wrote to appellants on August 15, 1942 (Ex. P.78), stating delivery time of all pending contracts extended automatically for period working stopped and until normal state of affairs recurred.
Strike ended, mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.
On December 5, 1942, Keshavlal and Ratilal approached Jasubhai (then in charge of mills management) for delivery; told contracts void, no delivery.
Jasubhai wrote to appellants on December 6, 1942 (Ex. P.62), contracts null and void, not binding.
At time of contracts, Chinubhai Lalbhai in charge of managing agency; on September 18, 1942, managing agency fell to Jasubhai and Babubhai.
Appellants wrote to respondent on December 17, 1942, respondent bound to deliver due to extension letter of August 15, 1942; threatened legal proceedings.
Respondent replied on December 20, 1942, repeating contentions.
Appellants formally demanded delivery in January and February 1943.
Suit filed on January 9, 1946, claiming Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 damages with interest and costs. Alleged suit in time due to acceptance of extension request.
Trial court (Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmedabad, Suit No. 10 of 1946) decreed appellants' claim on July 30, 1949, finding in favour on extension and limitation.
Bombay High Court Appeal No. 642 of 1949 dismissed suit on April 17, 1950: rejected oral evidence of acceptance, conduct not showing acceptance, letter vague/uncertain, suit barred by limitation.
Ratilal (PW1) evidence: 4-5 days after Aug 15 letter, met Chinubhai, accepted extension orally. No written confirmation.
Keshavlal corroborated Ratilal; after mills reopened, demanded delivery from Jasubhai.
Chinubhai evidence: Proposal under his instructions; similar to all constituents; oral acceptance likely but did not remember specifically.
No demand for delivery on original due dates.
Sauda books brought to trial court but not exhibited by either party.
Prices of goods rising at material time.
Respondent's pleas on contract invalidity and Laxmidas authority negatived in courts below.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was agreement between parties for extension of time for performance of contract.
Whether the proposal for extension in letter dated August 15, 1942 was vague and uncertain, rendering agreement void.

petitioner_arguments.text: Oral evidence of Ratilal and Keshavlal reliable; met Chinubhai and accepted extension orally 4-5 days after Aug 15 letter.
Conduct consistent: no demand on original dates, demanded after reopening; rising prices made extension beneficial.
Respondent's conduct shows prejudice, untenable pleas on contract validity.
Sauda books not produced by respondent infers endorsement of extension.
Second condition in letter surplusage, ignore per Nicolene; extension only for stoppage period.

respondent_arguments.text: No agreement on extension; oral evidence unreliable; conduct does not show acceptance.
Letter of Aug 15 vague/uncertain, especially 'till normal state of affairs recurred'; agreement void.
Contracts void, not binding; letter unauthorised.

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence of Ratilal and Keshavlal true; corroborated by conduct (no early demand, post-reopening demand); Chinubhai not inconsistent; probabilities favour acceptance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence and conduct show acceptance of proposal to extend time.

court_reasoning.text: Letter's second condition 'till normal state of affairs recurred' vague/uncertain; cannot define normalcy (political, mill working factors unspecified); no consensus on meaning.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement vague per s.29 Contract Act; plaint assumes only stoppage period.

court_reasoning.text: Nicolene distinguishable: second condition essential, not meaningless surplusage; both conditions must be agreed for valid extension under s.63.
Scammell supports: vague terms prevent enforceable contract.
Plea of vagueness allowable in appeal as pure law on document construction; no extrinsic evidence per s.93 Evidence Act.
Extension under s.63 requires mutual agreement, provable orally or by conduct.

holdings.text: Acceptance of extension proposal proved by oral evidence and conduct.
Agreement to extend time void for vagueness and uncertainty under s.29 Contract Act.
Suit barred by limitation due to no valid extension.

precedents_cited.relevance: Vague meaningless clause severable; here second condition essential, not surplusage.
Vague terms (hire-purchase) prevent enforceable contract; words fail to evince definite meaning.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: S.63: Promisee may extend time by agreement. S.29: Agreements void for uncertainty.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellate court may allow plea of law based on document construction.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No evidence admissible to remove vagueness from document.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, confirming High Court's dismissal of suit as barred by limitation due to vague extension agreement. Noted respondent's lack of bona fides but held vagueness fatal.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "the delivery time of all your pending contracts with us shall be automatically understood as extended for the period the working is stopped and till the normal state of affairs recurs."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Basis of extension proposal, held vague due to second condition.

key_quotes.text: "If these words, considered however broadly and untechnically and with due regard to all the just implications, fail to evince any definite meaning on which the court can safely act, the court has no choice but to say that there is no contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Scammell, applied to hold extension void.

key_quotes.text: "we confirm the finding of the High Court on the question of vagueness or uncertainty of the agreement to extend time and that must inevitably lead to the dismissal of the present appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
